perturbation.original_text: 7. Restrictive Covenants. 7.1 Solicitation of Employees. CONSULTANT agrees that during its consultancy for REIT and for a period of twelve (12) months immediately following the termination of its consultancy with the Company for any reason, whether with or without cause, it will not, for itself or any other person or entity: (a) solicit, induce, recruit or encourage any of the Company's employees, contractors, independent contractors or any person who provides services to the Company to terminate or reduce their employment or other relationship with the Company; (b) hire any individual who is (or was within the six (6) months immediately preceding such hiring, unless such employee was terminated from such employment by Company) an employee, exclusive contractor, or exclusive independent contractor of the Company; or (c) attempt to do any of the foregoing.
perturbation.changed_text: 7. Restrictive Covenants. 7.1 Solicitation of Employees. CONSULTANT agrees that during its consultancy for REIT it will not, for itself or any other person or entity: (a) solicit, induce, recruit or encourage any of the Company's employees to terminate or reduce their employment or other relationship with the Company; (b) hire any individual who is an employee of the Company; or (c) attempt to do any of the foregoing.
perturbation.explanation: This change significantly reduces the scope of the non-solicitation agreement. By removing the clause 'for a period of twelve (12) months immediately following the termination of its consultancy' and eliminating 'contractors, independent contractors or any person who provides services to the Company' and 'or was within the six (6) months immediately preceding such hiring, unless such employee was terminated from such employment by Company,' the agreement now only prevents solicitation of current employees *during* the consultancy. This omission introduces a legal risk because many jurisdictions, including Virginia where Gunston Consulting, LLC is based, recognize and enforce reasonable post-employment non-solicitation agreements to protect a company's legitimate business interests. The original clause provided more protection, but the modified version offers considerably less, potentially violating the standard of reasonable protection required under Virginia law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Virginia law regarding reasonable non-solicitation agreements, specifically concerning duration and scope necessary to protect legitimate business interests.

perturbation.original_text: 9.7 Indemnity. (a) Indemnity by the Company. The Company hereby agrees to indemnify and hold harmless Consultant against any and all losses, claims, damages, liabilities and expenses (including reasonable costs of investigation and legal counsel fees) to the extent not funded by applicable insurance, in addition to any liability the Company may otherwise have, arising out of, related to or based upon (i) any violation of law, rule or regulation by the Company or the Company's agents, employees, representatives or affiliates or (ii) any third party action or claim against the Company in which Consultant is alleged to be additionally liable. In this regard CONSULTANT shall be an additional insured under Company's applicable insurance coverages. Company shall provide CONSULTANT evidence of all such coverage.
perturbation.changed_text: 9.7 Indemnity. (a) Indemnity by the Company. The Company hereby agrees to indemnify and hold harmless Consultant against any and all losses, claims, damages, liabilities and expenses to the extent funded by applicable insurance, in addition to any liability the Company may otherwise have, arising out of, related to or based upon (i) any violation of law, rule or regulation by the Company or the Company's agents, employees, representatives or affiliates or (ii) any third party action or claim against the Company in which Consultant is alleged to be additionally liable. Company may provide CONSULTANT evidence of such coverage.
perturbation.explanation: This edit significantly weakens the Consultant's protection. The original clause states the consultant is held harmless 'to the extent not funded by applicable insurance', but now the clause states the consultant is held harmless 'to the extent funded by applicable insurance'. This means that the company only indemnifies the consultant if the insurance covers it. This is a significant change because it means the consultant might be responsible for any and all costs and legal fees that arise from any legal matters, where the company doesn't have appropriate insurance.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of indemnity law which require reasonable and adequate protection for the indemnitee (Consultant), potentially conflicting with the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing.

perturbation.original_text: 9.6 Governing Law; Jurisdiction. This Agreement shall be interpreted, construed, governed, and enforced according to the laws of the Commonwealth of Virginia, without giving effect to its conflict of laws principles. The Parties hereby agree and consent that any and all causes of action arising under this Agreement shall only have jurisdiction and venue in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia and/or the Circuit Court for Chesterfield County. Each of the parties consents to the jurisdiction and venue of either court for the resolution of all causes of action arising under this Agreement upon proper service of process.
perturbation.changed_text: 9.6 Governing Law; Jurisdiction. This Agreement shall be interpreted, construed, governed, and enforced according to the laws of the Commonwealth of Virginia, giving effect to its conflict of laws principles. The Parties hereby agree and consent that any and all causes of action arising under this Agreement shall have jurisdiction and venue at the discretion of the Company. Each of the parties consents to the jurisdiction and venue of either court for the resolution of all causes of action arising under this Agreement upon proper service of process.
perturbation.explanation: By omitting 'without giving effect to its conflict of laws principles' and adding 'giving effect to its conflict of laws principles' it would not be as straightforward which laws would be followed. By stating that the jurisdiction and venue would be at the discretion of the company, that could create a legal challenge of fairness.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Virginia law on conflict of laws and principles of fairness and impartiality in contractual dispute resolution.
